metadata.title: Bell OH-58 Kiowa
aws::graph::propositions: OH-58D Helicopter Operations in Task Force 118
OH-58D helicopter crews received deck landing training from the Navy.
OH-58D helicopter crews received underwater survival training from the Navy.
The number of OH-58D helicopters supporting Task Force 118 was reduced in November 1988.
OH-58D helicopters continued to operate from the Navy's Mobile Sea Base Hercules after November 1988.
OH-58D helicopters continued to operate from the frigate Underwood after November 1988.
OH-58D helicopters continued to operate from the destroyer Conolly after November 1988.
OH-58D operations primarily entailed reconnaissance flights at night.
Army helicopters usually rotated from the mobile sea base to a land base every seven to fourteen days.
Army helicopters usually rotated from other combatant ships to a land base every seven to fourteen days.
The rotation schedule depended on maintenance requirements.
The rotation schedule depended on ship scheduling.
An OH-58D helicopter crashed during night gunnery practice on 18 September 1989.
The OH-58D helicopter sank after crashing on 18 September 1989.
There was no loss of personnel in the OH-58D crash on 18 September 1989.
The Mobile Sea Base Hercules was deactivated in September 1989.
All but five OH-58D helicopters redeployed to the continental United States after the Mobile Sea Base Hercules was deactivated.

OH-58D operations primarily entailed reconnaissance flights at night.
Army helicopters usually rotated from the mobile sea base to a land base every seven to fourteen days.
Army helicopters usually rotated from other combatant ships to a land base every seven to fourteen days.
The rotation schedule depended on maintenance requirements.
The rotation schedule depended on ship scheduling.
An OH-58D helicopter crashed during night gunnery practice on 18 September 1989.
The OH-58D helicopter sank after crashing on 18 September 1989.

text:
The OH-58D helicopter crews involved in the operation received deck landing and underwater survival training from the Navy.
In November 1988, the number of OH-58D helicopters that supported Task Force 118 was reduced. However, the rotorcraft continued to operate from the Navy's Mobile Sea Base Hercules, the frigate Underwood, and the destroyer Conolly. OH-58D operations primarily entailed reconnaissance flights at night, and depending on maintenance requirements and ship scheduling, Army helicopters usually rotated from the mobile sea base and other combatant ships to a land base every seven to fourteen days. On 18 September 1989, an OH-58D crashed during night gunnery practice and sank, but with no loss of personnel. When the Mobile Sea Base Hercules was deactivated in September 1989, all but five OH-58D helicopters redeployed to the continental United States.
